Abyssinian: almond-shaped eyes, usually green or gold
short, fine coat with a distinctive "ticked" pattern
colors include ruddy, red, blue, or fawn
expressive face with a slightly concave profile.
Bengal: short coat with distinctive spotted or marbled patterns
coat colors often in shades of brown, gold, or snow (white)
large almond-shaped eyes, usually green or gold
tail with dark rings or a solid dark tip
Birman: Color-pointed coat (darker coloration on ears, face, paws, and tail)
White "gloves" on the front paws and "laces" on the back paws
Stocky build with a broad head
British Shorthair: Large, round eyes, often copper or gold in color
Egyptian Mau: distinctive coat pattern with spots scattered randomly across the body
coat colors include silver, bronze, and smoke
hind legs longer than the front legs, giving a "tippy-toe" appearance
characteristic "worried" expression due to the set of eyes and brow lines
Maine Coon: Prominent ruff of fur around the neck
Wide-set eyes, often with a piercing look
Polydactyl paws (extra toes) in some individuals
Persian: A prominent nose with a flat or nearly flat bridge
Ragdoll: Pointed color pattern, often with colors like seal, blue, chocolate, or lilac
V-shaped or an inverted "V" marking on the forehead
Floppy and relaxed posture when held
Rounded body with a broad chest
Russian Blue: slightly upturned mouth giving a subtle smile appearance
Siamese: color points on ears, face, paws, and tail (usually in shades of seal, chocolate, blue, or lilac)
american bulldog: Typically white or white with patches of brindle, brown, or black
Medium-sized ears, which can be cropped or natural
Moderate to long tail, thick at the base and tapering to a point
american pit bull terrier: broad head with a flat skull
ears that can be cropped or natural (half-prick or rose-shaped)
colors vary, including solid, brindle, and patched patterns
basset hound: tricolor coat (typically black, white, and brown)
pronounced dewlap (extra skin around the neck)
beagle: large, expressive brown or hazel eyes
distinctive vocalizations like howling and baying
boxer: often spotted in a boxing ring
posture indicating a readiness to fight or defend
possibly wearing headgear (in some training or amateur contexts)
chihuahua: smooth or long coat, often in various colors (fawn, black, white, chocolate, cream, etc.)
proportionally large head in comparison to its body
english cocker spaniel: Big, expressive eyes (often dark in color)
Common coat colors: black, liver, red, golden, or combinations including roan and particolor markings
english setter: coat colors typically white with speckles of black, blue, lemon, orange, or brown
long ears hanging close to the head
tail that feathers and tapers to a point
well-proportioned body with a lean, athletic build
german shorthaired: Coat color is typically liver (brown), liver and white, or liver roan
Long, floppy ears that hang close to the head
Tapered, slightly curved tail (often docked in some regions)
great pyrenees: Primarily white fur, though may have gray, badger, reddish-brown, or tan markings
Fluffy, plumed tail that is usually carried low or curled over the back
Proportionate head with a broad skull
Strong, muscular legs adapted for working and guarding livestock
havanese: various coat colors including white, black, grey, and brown
sturdy body with a height ranging from 8.5 to 11.5 inches
plume-like tail that curls over the back
japanese chin: Distinctive flat face with a short, broad muzzle
Feathered, V-shaped ears that drop down
Black and white or red and white coat
Plumed tail carried over the back
keeshond: fur often in shades of grey, black, and cream
bushy tail that curls over the back
dense mane of fur around the neck and shoulders
leonberger: coat colors typically include lion-yellow, golden, red, red-brown, and sandy
strong and broad head with a slightly domed forehead
medium-length ears that hang close to the head
miniature pinscher: colors typically include black, chocolate, red, or rust
newfoundland: Thick, water-resistant double coat, typically black, brown, grey, or Landseer (black and white)
Broad head with a strong and rounded skull
Small, dark eyes that are set deep into the face
Drooping ears, relatively small and shaped like a triangle
pomeranian: A plumed tail that curls over the back
Color variations including orange, black, white, blue, brown, cream, and more
pug: curled tail that often rests on the back
smooth, short coat, typically fawn or black
saint bernard: Dense, double coat that can be short or long
Coat color typically in white with red, black, or brindle markings
Distinctive reddish-brown "mask" around the eyes and ears
Broad head with a pronounced stop
samoyed: a smiling expression, often referred to as the "Sammy smile"
bushy tail that curls over the back
scottish terrier: Distinctive, wiry coat, often black, but can also be brindle or wheaten
Tail that is medium length and often carried straight or with a slight curve
Dark, almond-shaped eyes with a keen expression
shiba inu: curled tail that usually rests over its back
distinct coat colors, typically red, black and tan, or sesame (red with black-tipped hairs)
white fur on the chest, legs, and tip of the tail
staffordshire bull terrier: Broad head with pronounced cheek muscles
Distinct stop (where the forehead and the muzzle meet)
Colors including brindle, black, white, fawn, blue, or a combination of these
Strong, straight front legs and well-muscled hindquarters
Tail that is low set and tapers to a point, often described as "pump handle" in shape
wheaten terrier: floppy ears that hang close to the head
a tail that is typically held upright or slightly curved
long hair covering the face, often forming a "beard" and "eyebrows"
yorkshire terrier: typically tan and steel blue-colored fur
compact body with a straight back
often has a topknot or hair tied up on the head
feathery tail that is usually carried slightly higher than the back
